user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of print_perf_warnings:
```c
static void
print_perf_warnings (void)
{
  int newline_needed = 0;
#if defined (_DEBUG)
  fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: Running with debug asserts enabled, "
           "the performance is suboptimal.\n");
  newline_needed |=  ! 0;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#if defined(__GNUC__) && ! defined (__OPTIMIZE__)
  fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: The tools is compiled without enabled compiler "
           "optimisations, the performance is suboptimal.\n");
  newline_needed |=  ! 0;
#endif /* __GNUC__ && ! __OPTIMIZE__ */
#if defined(__GNUC__) && defined (__OPTIMIZE_SIZE__)
  fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: The tools is compiled with size-optimisations, "
           "the performance is suboptimal.\n");
#endif /* __GNUC__ && ! __OPTIMIZE__ */
#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  if (MHD_NO != MHD_is_feature_supported (MHD_FEATURE_DEBUG_BUILD))
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: The libmicrohttpd is compiled with "
             "debug asserts enabled, the performance is suboptimal.\n");
    newline_needed |=  ! 0;
  }
#endif /* MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701 */
  if (newline_needed)
    printf ("\n");
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to any of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 are present in the provided code. The code only uses fprintf/printf with string literals (including adjacent string literal concatenation which is performed at compile time), a few preprocessor checks, a call to MHD_is_feature_supported (not a string.h function) and simple integer logic for newline_needed. None of these perform pointer-based string handling (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.), so there are no places that could violate Rule 21.17 in this fragment.
